Description: Lower body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; glaze fired red-brown; interior glazed; exterior glazed streakily save for rather narrow reserved band in handle zone; inscription on interior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2 (possibly)
Curator's comments: Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this cup, the profile and decoration finds parallels to his Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. The location of the inscription is unusual. Inscribed dedications on South Ionian cups tend to be on the exterior surface of the rim or handle zone.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.620) (Phase 3)
